titleStmt.title: M49. [Anon: Anon died around 1477...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned, and undated. 8p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M49. [Anon: Anon died around 1477...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned, and undated. 8p. Paginated 3-10. On verso of p. 8-9 her: People one would have liked to have met. Holograph fragment. 2p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.s:
died round 18787. It was the printed book
with the authors name attached that killed him. After that
the audience was separate from the singer. After that
the song was attached to the singer. Anon gives place to
xmxmxmxmxmx or or Peter; he lives in a house
and he has books.

div.p:
[The heart of this vast proliferation (prolieferation) of printed pages
remains the song. The song has the same power over the reader
in the 20th century (cen ury) as over the hearer in the 11th. To enjoy
singing, to enjoy hearing the sing, must be the most
deep rooted, the toughest of human instincts comparable
for persistency with the instinct of self preservation
It is indeed the instinct of self preservation.
Only when we put two and two together--two pencil strokes,
two written words, two bricks do we overcome dissolution (doissolution)
and set up some stake against oblivion. The passion with
which we seek out these creations (creation) and attempt endlessly,
perpetually, to make them is of a piece with the instinct
that sets us preserving our (out) bodies, with clothes, food,
roofs, from destruction.]

But With the broughtcame into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books themselves,
and the readers of books. If science were so advanced that
we could at this moment X ray the singers mind as she moved we should
find a nimbus surrounding the song; a [stream? steam?] (steeam) of
influences. Some we can name--education; class;
the pressure of society. But they are so many, and so

interwoven and so obscure that it is simpler to invent
for them nonsense names--- say and . Nin
Crot and Pully are always at their work, tugging, obscuring,
distorting. Some are visible only to the writer. Others
only to the reader. More and more complex ( omplex) do they become as
time passes. The song beneath is only to be discovered (disocovered)
in a flash of recognition; Some say they feel it when their
beards bristle; others that a thrill runs down the nerves
of the thigh. But the song is there still. For example:

That babbling, child like, story telling singer, that
gossip at the farm yard door, that innocent (inno ent) eyed, naked,
lustful, nowalternately obscene and ( n ) devout singer, who was now and ag
a great artist died in 14787, And with him died
the part of his song that the audience sang--the voice that
filled in pauses, and added sometimes a nonsensical (nonsenical) chorus
To follow his fortunes further we must turn to one of those
commentators who tell us us so much about the invisible
influences. about Nin Crot and Pulley.

But for him of course we have to wait until winter
was past; until time has drawn its blue veil

over the horizon; until there is a past. ThenWhen Anon
is long (lomg) dead, and the (adnthe) Pil have gone
their way, somebody looks back. He is a representative man,
that is he hxxxxx is often repeated, in other centuries, with little variation.
He-- was his name-- is the first of that long line
of leisured and learned men who have time to think about the
past in the (hthe) quiet of the parsonage. Like , like
the parson of , hehad a library; and dug up
coins. He already sees the present against the background
of the past. The past has become (necome) so settled, so ordered,
that the (yhe) present looks ungainly and degenerate against it.
There is too much comfort; too much silver; too many pillows.
The young , are not the men their fathers (father)
were. The smoke is drawn off from their sitting rooms
by chimneys (chimensy), so that instead of being salted and
hardened (hardned) by thesmoke eddying from the fire in the
brazier, they are tender and subject to rheumatism. They
dress most fantastically compared (comparded) with their ancestors.

But the English seen past as seen by Harrison only served
to show up the physical, the material change --the
change that had come over houses, furniture (furniuture) and clothing.
To show up the change in the mind, there was no
English pattern. There was no English literature, to show
up the decline of English literature. "English " says the
" had gone underground (undergrounf) for two centuries...

English had gone (gon ) down stairs into the kitchen, into the
farmyard. had sung his song at the back door
in a jargon that was as uncouth to as to ourselves (ourslves):

Icham for woing al forwake
Wery no water in wore

An hendy hap ichable yghent
Ichot from hevene it is me sent

-- the (yhhe) words were as difficult for him to spell out as
for ourselves; and more painful. For they reminded him of
his lack of intellectual ancestry (ansctery). He goes back a very little way - to
, , . For him it was a very sxxxx
little way. So, to have ancestors (anscestors), he must cross the
; his ancestors by way of (o f) the mind are
the Greeks and the Romans. His page is burdened particularly [illeg.]with these
proofs of good breeding. Hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm
, ; ; --they prove his good
breeding, as we prove ours by going back (vback) to , to
. The ancients (anicents) occupied the same place in
mind that the Elizabethans occupy in ours.
Those were the great books that were chained to the
shelves (selves) of the college libraries. The learned read them.
And in Harrisons day the nobles. "...our ancient ladies
of the court" were to be found reading the (th) holy scriptures
as they did their needlework (needlwwork); and histories. The noble
ladies wxmxmxmmxmxx if they had a turn for reading (rading), must
read Latin and Greek (reek), for xxxxmxmxmx English literature
xmxmxmmxmxmxmxxxxmxmxmxx not enough (nough) English
literature to keep a healthy appetite in being. They had to learn

French, and Latin, and many were driven by hunger to master
Greek.

In the minds background then stood the almost featureless
Roman busts-- , ; ;
overpowering , and and . And in
the foreground there is the house, no longer a hut made of
branches; no longer thick with smoke; There is a pillow now,
instead of the old log with the hollow in it; and glass
in the windows; and silver to drink from. The ceilings are
curiously worked . Beyond the house there is
; a fine city; and [illeg.] ships riding at anchor;
and Inns upon the road (raod) and there though he cannot
see himself, is , querulous yet kindly, using language (languag)
to his patron that would have shocked (schoked) his
ancestors (anecsotrs) -- words as ornate as the carvings and
decorations (decorati s) that shocked him. And he digs in the earth for
coins has never gone more than forty miles from
in ; has a father; and owns a mastiff. The age of anonymity is over
when we begin to furnish out the individualwriter with
xmxmxxx his own private features.

"with vain
affectation of
eloquence to
paint out a
rotten
sepulchre

div.p:
But how little even the most diligent, the most laborious,
of these searchers can find of (o) the human being.
They polish the shell only. They lingerremain upon the habits and
the furniture, the house itself, It is as if we were told
that the novelist had a tweed suit,
six hats, some bowlers some top hats; and used to
take a walking stick in his hand and when he walked;
and had his meat cooked on a coal fire, by a woman whose
name was perhaps Joan. It is the house that (hous t) they preserve with
all their friction; not the tenant of the house. Save for
and and for the voice of singing
at the back door the English might e be a dumb race who
enjoyed and suffered tacitly; a race of merchants,
soldiers and priests (preists), who left behind them
stone houses, cultivated (cu lt vated) fields and vast cathedrals.
but not words. The great house is silent; Only the furniture
remains, stiff and ornate, fantastic (fanatstic) and uncushioned.

At [illeg.]old sat at her table writing
But her letter to is as intricate and formal (foral) as a [illeg.]
state paper. It is a letter written from the pulpit
She admonishes and preaches. She is violent and irate.
xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm.They are letters from
a counsellor to a confederate (conferedate); with [admonishing?] a [illeg.] full of the wickedness of men,
the dangers and deceits (decits) of the world; and the praise of her [illeg.]
God. "God keep us sound in the (inmthe) faith and send us health
and a care to please God above all...." [illeg.] She drops into
Greek and Latin. If she has (ha ) to descend (decend) the actual in a [illeg.] strawberry (starbeery)
strawberry (stra erry) it withwish (w h) warning and craft. "I have sent them by

p.hi: People one would (wd) have liked to have met

div.p:
: not face to face; but with a pane
of glass between us Not in her [illeg.], but at
: passing [left?] & The first roads would (wd) have
An adventure

boy of my kitchen (kr chen), a shrewd (shrwed)-witted boy and prettily ca
cachetizes, but yet an untoward crafty boy.... Be not (bot) speedy (speddy)
of speech, nor (not) talk (tal) suddenly, but where discretion (disctretion)
requireth, and that soberly then...Let not Lawson, that
fox, be acquainted (acquanited) with my letters..." & [illeg.]
The sound of the Bible is in her ears, her prose takes
its solemn pleats; and the prose of the bible will not
adapt [illeg.] itself to the natural, to the easy, to the colloquial.
It is a garment to be put on when the mind is
erect and dignified.

Using ( sing) then only the prose of the Bible when they
speak to each other familiarly (familiark), the Elizabethans are
hidden from us. They are never subttle. They are never
shaded. Carnation and snow (snaow); ebony and gold meet on their
faces. We see when we (he) look at them wearing farthingales (farthibgales) and ruffs;
young (yong) bodies stiffly sewn into slashed doublets;
young (youn) faces raised on a starched collar; and the
bodies of young women serving only to prop a heavy quilted
dress stuckabout with huge pearls.

The writer therefore, conscious of his plebian (plbeian) birth
hesitated on the threshold of the great room.
The writer (Thw riter) therefore, who had only lately emerged from anonymity (anonymy)
hesitated on the threshold of the great room. He was
now separate from his audience; but he was after all,
closely (cloesly) connected with it. He was [finally?] still unspecialised,
undifferentiated. The eye was stimulated by the crimsons
and golds and greens (greesn) of the clothing. by the angles and the
patterns on the ceiling. The ear too was stimulated and
filled. Books were read aloud; each word was given

given sharpness and substance by the speaking voice.
And there was the pear shaped lute. Lilt, rhythm, melody
was added to the substance and sharpness of words. In his
mind there was a His mind was full of half born, still
adhesive, undifferentiated words still; old words;
new words; French words; Latin words. No grammar bound
them tightly together (ogether). They could stretch ; they could reflect (refelc)
many colours; follow many tunes; they could take the rhythm (rhym)
of the lute; they could sxxxxxxxx be danced to, or sung to.
But They could not yet rhythm (rhtym) of the speaking voice.
[Whether he was to write (wrote) or to sing or to paint was
an open question. [The arts were closely related]
For a moment there is a pause on the threshold of the
great Elizabethan (Elizabthan) room. when the artist is not wholly
writer, wholly painter, or wholly musician.
was the natural product of that momentary pause
on the threshold.

It seems possible for a moment that the great English
art is going to be painting, or music. not literature
And then for some (soem) reason makes (make ) his choice; the great
English art is to be poetry.
